“Not Secure” Warnings to Show on All Non-HTTPS Pages in July 2018

Google continues pushing the web towards a more secure future with Phase 3 of its multi-year plan to mark non-HTTPS sites as "not secure." Check out our review of the timeline of Google's march to HTTPS and find out what is coming next.

Tech News

Facebook and Cambridge Analytica Face Class Action Lawsuit

Lawyers from the UK and the US have filed a class action lawsuit in federal court in Delaware alleging that Facebook, Cambridge Analytica, and two other companies misused the personal data of more one million people in the UK and over 70 million people in the US. This article describes the context of that lawsuit and summarizes the claims and responses by the companies. Read the complaint on Justia Dockets.

Facebook & Cambridge Analytica: What We Know, What They Knew, & Where That Leaves Us

Search Engine Land has compiled this timeline of Facebook's privacy problems and comments on their individual and collective significance. The author predicts that Facebook's response to the present crisis, and its users' response in return, will have a serious impact on the viability of the social network giant as a dominant marketing channel.

Sen. Warner: Congress Needs Silicon Valley to Help Fix Privacy

Senator Mark Warner (D-VA), vice-chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, has been asking technology companies to address privacy issues. Now, after Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg testified before Congress, Senator Warner is in good company in calling upon tech companies to work with Congress rather than against it. CNET interviewed the senator after Zuckerberg's testimony and summarizes the highlights in this article.

Senators Introduce Privacy ‘Bill of Rights’ to Protect Consumer Data

In early April, Senators Edward J. Markey (D-MA) and Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) introduced a bill aimed at protecting American consumers' personal data online. Known as the Customer Online Notification for Stopping Edge-provider Network Transgressions (CONSENT) Act, the legislation would impose an obligation on the Federal Trade Commission (FTC)—the agency tasked with protecting America's consumers—to establish privacy protections for consumers of online goods and services.

‘Right to Be Forgotten’ Can Apply to Criminals: UK High Court Rules Against Google

A High Court in the UK (roughly comparable to federal district court in the US) recently ruled that Google must remove from its search results references to the plaintiffs' criminal histories. In that case, two businessmen requested that Google remove the references, and Google refused. The court's decision was based on a "right to be forgotten" that is gaining a foothold since the Court of Justice of the European Union recognized it as a right in a 2014 ruling.

LA Councilman Asks City Attorney to “Review Possible Legal Action” Against Waze

A Los Angeles city councilman is asking the city to look into taking legal action against the navigation app Waze (owned by Google) for routing large volumes of traffic into small neighborhood streets, causing traffic disruption and accidents. This article reports that no one from Waze or Google has responded to requests to meet with local politicians to discuss the issue.

Facebook Takes the Punches While Rest of Silicon Valley Ducks

While Facebook's mishandling of users' personal data has been in the spotlight in recent months, many other Silicon Valley companies that collect huge amounts of user data have gone practically unnoticed. Most notably, Google has maintained a relatively low profile despite having nearly double the advertising presence as Facebook and serving millions more users across its range of products. This article explores the reasons behind the disparity but anticipates that Google is likely next in line for scrutiny.

Microsoft, Facebook, Oracle Among 34 Firms to Join Cybersecurity Tech Accord

Earlier this month, a handful of tech companies, including Microsoft, Oracle and Facebook signed the Cybersecurity Tech Accord, an agreement aimed at defending against cyberattacks. By signing the agreement, the companies express their commitment to fortifying defenses against cyberattacks and to not helping governments launch cyberattacks against innocent citizens or enterprises. Notably, Amazon, Apple, and Google are not signatories to the accord, but this article quotes an analyst as explaining their absence as potentially attributable to conflicts with governments with which they already have agreements.

Amazon Reveals It Has More Than 100 Million Prime Members

Jeff Bezos tends to be reticent about making public statistics associated with the online shopping giant, Amazon. Bucking tradition, Bezos recently shared some information about Amazon’s membership program, Prime, which includes benefits like free shipping, e-books, and music and video streaming. In mid-April, Bezos stated via letter that Amazon Prime has 100 million members. This is 10 million users more than 2017 estimates by outside analysts.

SEO News

Google’s Direct Answers Now Shown on 10% of SERPs

In a return to Google’s more direct answers search results format, 10% of mobile SERPs now show a direct answer box. The statistic represents a 1.4% increase of direct answers in April as compared to March. This month-over-month increase is one of the greatest on record, according to data from RankRanger’s most recent report on US-based mobile SERP features. Such data is noteworthy, because it seems to demonstrate that Google is increasing its efforts to produce more immediate answers to user queries.

Google Officially Rolls Out ‘More Results’ Search Button On Mobile

Last month, Google transitioned from testing its mobile “More results” search button to officially launching it. The announcement came via a tweet from an official Google account and confirmed that the “More results” button is intended to replace its previous “Next” button, which displayed a new page of mobile search results when clicked on.

Google Chrome to Prevent Videos With Sound from Autoplaying

Most videos with sound will be disabled automatically in Google’s latest version of Chrome for desktop. There will, however, be exceptions for videos that Google thinks individual users are interested in. This is determined by three factors, one of which is whether the user has viewed the video before. Google is taking the same step with video ads on its desktop and mobile browsers. Videos that are designed to autoplay without sound remain unaffected.

Google Search Console is Notifying Site Owners About AMP Issues

Google Search Console has been sending email notifications to site owners related to issues which are specific to social media on AMP pages. These issues do not affect how web pages show up in search results. User experience is, however, often considered an indirect ranking factor, one that Google itself stresses. This makes Google Search Console’s email notifications useful tools that site owners can employ to quickly address social media issues on AMP pages and ensure an optimal user experience.

Google Expanding Types of Predictions They Remove from Autocomplete

In a recent post on the Google Blog, search liaison Danny Sullivan revealed that Google expects to expand the types of autocomplete predictions it prohibits. Over the years, autocomplete predictions have induced public outrage over alleged racism or political party bias. While Google has steadfastly maintained that its autocomplete results merely reflect the behavior of its search users, the company will nevertheless be removing predictions that it determines are against its guidelines going forward.

Social Media News

Facebook Exits Anti-Privacy Alliance It Formed With Comcast and Google

Facebook recently donated $200,000 to create a $1 million fund opposing California’s Consumer Privacy Act, in conjunction with Google, Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon. The Act is a ballot question that California residents could be voting on this coming November. If approved, the law would simplify the process by which consumers can discover what information has been collected about them and allow them to opt out of the sale or sharing of such information. Following Facebook’s privacy breach that affected upwards of 87 million users, however, the company has decided to drop its opposition to this law and stated that it will not donate additional money to the fund going forward.

Here’s How to Use Twitter to Dominate the Google Search Results

Twitter may be able to help your firm displace negative reviews and unflattering content, as well as build a strong brand identity. According to Search Engine Land contributor research, 30 of the top 50 worldwide brand names have Twitter account pages that show up on page one of the Google search results for their name. This article provides ten tips on how your firm can use tweets to enhance its Google search ranking.

Snapchat Now Lets Advertisers Sell Products Directly Through Lenses

Snapchat has unveiled a new feature that allows advertisers to sell products to users without leaving the app. Within Lenses, users can click on links to learn more about a product, or make purchases directly within the app. This move builds on the company’s Sponsored Lenses service, which debuted in 2015 and allowed advertisers to create branded filters for selfies. Snap states that 70 million users engage with Lenses daily.

Facebook Facial Recognition Faces Class Action Lawsuit

A California federal court judge has ruled that Facebook must face a class action lawsuit filed against it by users claiming that the company gathered their biometric information without their explicit consent. This information has allegedly been used as part of Facebook’s facial recognition technology, which provides “tag suggestions” to users by identifying their friends in uploaded photos. The plaintiffs claim that this technology violates Illinois law.

Facebook and Instagram Data and Privacy Updates

Facebook and Instagram have rolled out various updates to their data and privacy practices. Highlights include efforts by Facebook to limit the extent of user data being shared with third parties for advertising purposes, and to curb ad targeting without user consent. Instagram interface and data access for developers is being significantly reduced as a result of Facebook’s policy changes.

How to Reshare an Instagram Post to Your Instagram Stories

Instagram has been conducting a trial run with a limited number of users to allow them to reshare any public post in their Instagram stories. Though this is not an official “regram” feature, it may be a precursor to that development. Business users can reshare posts via their Instagram stories to highlight industry news, showcase company services, or cross-promote their own posts.

Legal Industry News

ABA Condemns Suspension of Justice Department’s Legal Orientation Program for Immigrants

In a recent press release, the ABA criticized the Justice Department’s decision to suspend funding for a “know your rights” program for immigrants in order to review it for cost efficiency. The program was funded through 19 nonprofits, including two affiliated with the ABA, and sought to provide information and education regarding the immigration court system. The Justice Department has reportedly made other changes to address the significant backlog at the immigration courts, which are housed within the Department, such as evaluating immigration judges’ performance based on how quickly they adjudicate cases.

Proposal Would End Admission-Test Requirement for Accredited Law Schools

The Standards Review Committee of the ABA’s Section of Legal Education and Admissions to the Bar has put forth a proposal to end the requirement for accredited law schools to use an admissions test. The proposal advocates that law schools instead focus on the use of academic credentials and attrition in evaluating accreditation compliance. This prospective change comes as acceptance of the GRE continues to increase at law schools across the country. The current version of the rule at issue requires schools using an admissions test other than the LSAT to demonstrate the validity and reliability of that test in helping to determine whether an individual can complete that school’s legal degree program.

Performance on February 2018 Bar Exam Sinks to Record Low

Data indicate that scores on the February 2018 bar exam were exceptionally low, with the average MBE score being 1.3 points lower than the year before. While the percentage of repeat test-takers overall did not go up, their scores went down relative to 2017. Approximately 70% of February’s test-takers had taken the exam at least once before.

New Gmail and Outlook Security Features Will Appeal to Lawyers

Security enhancements in Gmail and Outlook will be welcomed by many in the legal industry in light of recent ABA authority encouraging attorneys to use encrypted email when communicating electronically with clients. The upcoming changes include a possible “confidential mode” feature within Gmail, and user controls limiting recipients’ abilities to print, copy, or download emails. Outlook users will be able to encrypt individual emails, and share password links to secure documents.

Lawyers Weren’t As Lonely Back When Technology Wasn’t As Prevalent In Practicing Law

In this column, a longtime California attorney and mediator shares her perspective on the benefits of practicing law before technology had become as enmeshed in the profession as it is today. Law libraries and shared office facilities previously served some of the same functions that networking events and internet research do today. While this evolution has arguably increased efficiency, it may also be increasing loneliness and related competence issues among a new generation of attorneys.
